fields.headline: Rocky road to draft charter
fields.bodyText: January 30 The first election since Saddam Hussein's fall brings a coalition of Shias and Kurds to power. A boycott by the once-dominant Sunni Arab minority leaves them with only a handful of seats in parliament March 16 Parliament holds its first meeting in Baghdad's fortified green zone April 28 After weeks of horse-trading over posts, parliament approves a cabinet headed by a Shia prime minister, Ibrahim al-Jaafari. A parliamentary committee to draft a new constitution is formed July 5 To compensate for their under-representation, 15 Sunnis from outside parliament are added to an expanded 71-member constitution committee July 20 Sunni committee members briefly suspend work on the constitution after two of their members are assassinated a day earlier August 7 President Jalal Talabani hosts a series of top-level meetings to try to break the talks deadlock August 15 A self-imposed deadline for presenting a draft constitution to parliament arrives with no deal, so parliament extends the deadline by a week August 22 A draft is presented to parliament, but not voted on, as Kurds and Shias continue talks to try to get Sunnis on board August 25 A planned session of parliament to rubber-stamp the constitution is abandoned as wrangling continues August 28 Kurds and Shias admit defeat in bringing Sunni negotiators on board and submit the draft to parliament, clearing the way for a referendum on October 15
